awd_titl_txt: NM Green: Advancing Sustainable Construction Technology Education
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a growing need for more technicians in the area of green construction technology as well as sustainable design and sustainable construction techniques. With growth in green construction jobs, the challenge is on educating the local workforce with the knowledge and skills necessary to obtain and succeed in these jobs. The University of New Mexico and Central New Mexico Community College will collaborate on this project resulting in the development of (1) a certificate program in green construction technologies to provide students with the necessary skills that lead to workforce development, (2) a pathway for students to participate in an internship program and dual credit courses (high school and college credit), and (3) outreach and mentoring efforts to expose underrepresented students to STEM fields, specifically construction technology and engineering. 

With a strong evaluation plan, the project will generate new knowledge about the skillset needed and the challenges faced in educating green construction technicians. The collaborative team of University of New Mexico and Central New Mexico Community College faculty will work to implement academic experiences relevant to green construction and sustainability.  Over 400 students will be impacted.  One of the key deliverables will be developing a model for internships, outreach, recruitment, and mentoring for underrepresented students. The knowledge gained will be shared with other institutions that have a focus on green construction technology and sustainability.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a partnership between the University of New Mexico (UNM) and Central New Mexico Community College (CNM) to build a pipeline for students to flow from high school through post-secondary education to a job in green construction. The major activities in this project included:

(1) Developing a certificate program in sustainable building technology at CNM to provide students with the necessary skills to obtain jobs in this field;

(2) Developing a pipeline of students focused on green construction technology through the implementation of an internship program and development of dual credit (high school and college credit) courses; and

(3) Attracting underrepresented minority students to STEM fields, specifically construction engineering and management, through outreach, recruitment, and mentoring activities.

The certificate in Sustainable Building Technology is housed in the CNM School of Applied Technologies (see attached informational flier). As part of the certificate program, CNM developed a course called ?Sustainable Building Practices? which has been taken by over 100 students in the first two years and has been offered at a local alternative high school for dual high school/college credit. This course has introduced sustainability concepts to a wide range of typically underrepresented students. Student demographics show that the proportion of underrepresented students in this course has been 2% Asian, 57% Hispanic, and 8% Native American. The gender breakdown was 59% male and 41% female.

This project also provided internships to over 50 students to encourage them to continue their education in green construction. Students interned at a variety of business including construction contractors, green building consultants, and energy companies. Students also had an opportunity to work on a green building project to provide sustainable housing. Over 80% of students in the internship program agreed or strongly agreed that their internship experience made them more confident so that they can succeed in the future. A majority of students placed in internships identified as Hispanic, Latinx, Mexican, or Native American.

A major outcome of this project has been the high level of interest from students who are typically underrepresented in technology and, more specifically, in construction technology. Project activities, such as new courses, internships, outreach (see attached photo), and mentoring have attracted hundreds of students from diverse backgrounds with the intent of interesting them in continuing their education and career in sustainable construction technology. In addition, this project has hosted dozens of teachers at summer sustainability workshops with the goal that these teachers will further educate their students in this important topic.
